text: Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Bill Vernon and Daryl Lane. Of all the themes handled by science fiction authors, that of alien contact has been one of the most consistently popular and fascinating. For a good reason, too. Aliens, whether they be the hostile bug-eyed monsters of the old pulp magazines or the friendly creatures of close encounters of the third kind, have always been one of the biggest attractions of science fiction. In the past, stories of alien contact were usually written as thrillers, with the sole and simple intention of scaring readers. H.G. Wells' The War of the Worlds is probably the best example of that type of story. But that's changed. Many contemporary writers have provided more thoughtful treatments of aliens, deepening the realism and the significance of narratives of alien contact. Of course, before you can have a story of alien contact, you have to have some aliens. One of the most provocative descriptions of aliens in all of science fiction is found in Larry Niven's and Jerry Pornell's The Moat in God's Eye. The success of that book is largely due to the unique and ingenious aliens, the Moaties, that Niven created for the story. It's interesting, though, that Niven says he doesn't really create aliens for a story, but suggests that it's the other way around. I always design aliens for themselves. I almost never design an alien to match a story. The story, some story will eventually include the alien. The alien stands for himself. There are two particularly fascinating things that Niven incorporated into these Moaties. One is the fact that they are not symmetrical. They have a head, torso, legs, and arms, as humans do. But the arms are disproportionate. One is small and thin, the other is large and powerful. Right. Niven says he took that idea from studying the structures of living creatures on Earth. In that case, I had the idea that I was following a progression with a protozoan, with an amoeba. You get radial symmetry inside and out. Move up a goodly distance and you find starfishes with radial symmetry on the outside and bilateral symmetry on the inside. Move up a little further, you find flatworms and worms of all stance. At the level of bilateral symmetry inside and out. Go as far as a human, you find bilateral symmetry on the outside and no symmetry, well, half symmetrical on the inside. The lungs look symmetrical, the kidneys look symmetrical, the intestines look like somebody dropped a plate of spaghetti. I tried to move on to the next step, bilaterally unsymmetrical on the outside. And I got the original Modi, which was the engineer for them. The other ingenious idea Niven developed for the Modis is the way they construct and use machines. They're highly skilled tool users, but they have no standard pre-manufactured machines, parts, or tools. They simply alter or reshape whatever they find around them at the time to suit their needs. Niven says that particular idea just came to him. It seemed interesting and even logical. I was just playing with ideas at that point, and that one seemed like a fun one. It also seemed likely enough, if you've got a critter with not much intelligence except in the direction of tool making and tool altering, then why not? But the thing has to keep testing its ability or it will lose it. It might as well be designing something every time it needs a specific machine. Besides the ingenuity Niven demonstrated in creating the Modis, he and Pornel also weaved some unexpected twists into the first contact theme. A reader interested in aliens, or more specifically in first contact, can't afford to overlook the Moat in God's eye. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. The Science Fiction Association Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Daryl Lane. And to Bill Vernon. The so-called new wave in science fiction, which began in the mid-60s, was simply a new way of writing traditional science fiction. There were changes, for instance, in... ...the modernization was given more emphasis. ...sex and religion, that science fiction hadn't really... ...the new wave changed the stereotyped science fiction formulas that... ...since the pulp days of the 20s, 30s, and 40s. Frederick Pohl, who's been an author, an editor, and an agent in the field of science fiction, has something to say about that change. The new wave was an attempt, I guess, 15 years ago or more, of a number of writers to break away from the traditional kinds of fiction. In fact, most of them didn't want to call it science fiction anymore. They wanted to call it speculative fiction, or... And they were interested, merrily, in writing about the inner space, rather than... ...the second, really, a lot of them... ...in things like... ...and rock music and so on. But... ...in the... ...rather bitter internal... ...stool that went on in science fiction, a lot of people take the science one way or the other. I think... ...people... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ... ...

segments.text: Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us.
This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy.
And here are your hosts.
This is Bill Vernon and Daryl Lane.
Of all the themes handled by science fiction authors, that of alien contact has been one of the most consistently popular and fascinating.
For a good reason, too.

Aliens, whether they be the hostile bug-eyed monsters of the old pulp magazines or the friendly creatures of close encounters of the third kind, have always been one of the biggest attractions of science fiction.
In the past, stories of alien contact were usually written as thrillers, with the sole and simple intention of scaring readers.
H.G. Wells' The War of the Worlds is probably the best example of that type of story.
But that's changed.
Many contemporary writers have provided more thoughtful treatments of aliens, deepening the realism and the significance of narratives of alien contact.
Of course, before you can have a story of alien contact, you have to have some aliens.
One of the most provocative descriptions of aliens in all of science fiction is found in Larry Niven's and Jerry Pornell's The Moat in God's Eye.
The success of that book is largely due to the unique and ingenious aliens, the Moaties, that Niven created for the story.
It's interesting, though, that Niven says he doesn't really create aliens for a story, but suggests that it's the other way around.
I always design aliens for themselves. I almost never design an alien to match a story.
The story, some story will eventually include the alien. The alien stands for himself.
There are two particularly fascinating things that Niven incorporated into these Moaties.
One is the fact that they are not symmetrical.
They have a head, torso, legs, and arms, as humans do.
But the arms are disproportionate.
One is small and thin, the other is large and powerful.
Right. Niven says he took that idea from studying the structures of living creatures on Earth.
In that case, I had the idea that I was following a progression with a protozoan, with an amoeba.
You get radial symmetry inside and out.
Move up a goodly distance and you find starfishes with radial symmetry on the outside and bilateral symmetry on the inside.
Move up a little further, you find flatworms and worms of all stance.
At the level of bilateral symmetry inside and out.
Go as far as a human, you find bilateral symmetry on the outside and no symmetry, well, half symmetrical on the inside.
The lungs look symmetrical, the kidneys look symmetrical, the intestines look like somebody dropped a plate of spaghetti.
I tried to move on to the next step, bilaterally unsymmetrical on the outside.
And I got the original Modi, which was the engineer for them.
The other ingenious idea Niven developed for the Modis is the way they construct and use machines.
They're highly skilled tool users, but they have no standard pre-manufactured machines, parts, or tools.
They simply alter or reshape whatever they find around them at the time to suit their needs.
Niven says that particular idea just came to him.
It seemed interesting and even logical.
I was just playing with ideas at that point, and that one seemed like a fun one.
It also seemed likely enough, if you've got a critter with not much intelligence except in the direction of tool making and tool altering, then why not?
But the thing has to keep testing its ability or it will lose it.
It might as well be designing something every time it needs a specific machine.
Besides the ingenuity Niven demonstrated in creating the Modis, he and Pornel also weaved some unexpected twists into the first contact theme.
A reader interested in aliens, or more specifically in first contact, can't afford to overlook the Moat in God's eye.
This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas.
